did.head: Overview

origination.label: Creator:
origination.corpname: Stanford University. Committee of Educational Inquiry.

did.unittitle: Stanford University, Committee of Educational Inquiry, records
did.abstract: Records include correspondence, minutes, reports, newsletters, and other materials, 1952-57. Nationally, the committees considered three basic topics: aims of liberal arts education, curriculum, and methods of instruction. The Stanford committee addressed the issues of college credit for high school work and the relative merits of the semester and quarter systems. Also included in the collection are minutes, correspondence, and agendas concerning the spring 1957 program of the California Folklore Society, held at Stanford and chaired by Aurelio M. Espinosa, Jr.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

acqinfo.p: Gift of Aurelio M. Espinosa, Jr.

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Ownership & Copyright
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94304-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/pubserv/permissions.html.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Stanford University, Committee of Educational Inquiry, Records (SC0113). Department of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Sketch
bioghist.p: The Stanford Committee of Educational Inquiry was part of a four-year project involving eleven universities, sponsored by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, to enlist faculty aid in the formulation of educational policies. The members of the Stanford committee were Graham P. Du Shane, George S. Parks, William C. Bark, and Aurelio M. Espinosa, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Collection
scopecontent.p: Records include correspondence, minutes, reports, newsletters, and other materials, 1952-1957. Nationally, the committees considered three basic topics: aims of liberal arts education, curriculum, and methods of instruction. The Stanford committee addressed the issues of college credit for high school work and the relative merits of the semester and quarter systems. Also included in the collection are minutes, correspondence, and agendas concerning the spring 1957 program of the California Folklore Society, held at Stanford and chaired by Aurelio M. Espinosa, Jr.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence between the Carnegie Foundation, Stanford Committee on Educational Inquiry,(C.E.I.), other C.E.I. committees, and schools in reference to C.E.I. projects.

did.unittitle: letters addressed to the Stanford C.E.I. committee chairman from schools or individuals requesting a copy of the C.B. I. report on the relative merits of the Semester and Quarter Systems.

scopecontent.p: newsletters, reading materials, members, conferences, etc., and correspondence between the Carnegie Foundation and C.E.I. committee members.

did.unittitle: minutes, committee member's forms, progress reports, faculty questionnaire, Interim Report on the Semester and Quarter System and budget expenditures of the Stanford C.E.I. Committee

scopecontent.p: Progress reports, project reports, interim reports on the semester and quarter systems, and an assessment of the C.E.I. project

did.unittitle: Minutes, correspondence, program agendas, etc., concerning the meeting of California Folklore Society chaired by Dr. Aurelio M. Espinoza, Jr.
